title: How to Make a Yarn Wreath

steps.headline: Obtain the needed supplies.
steps.description: (See list at bottom of this page.)

steps.headline: Choose yarn colors that coordinate with each other.
steps.description: This can easily become a Christmas wreath with red and green yarn colors, an Easter wreath with pastels, a spring wreath with pale green, blue and yellow, etc etc.

steps.headline: Wrap each ball of yarn, either from yarn alone, or using a Styrofoam ball as a base to conserve yarn.
Fasten the ends of the yarn securely with a pin or glue.
Make at least 20 balls, using your wreath form as a guide so you know how many you need to cover it.
Fasten the balls onto or into a wreath form.
steps.description:
There are two easy ways to handle this. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/5_preformed_wreath_205.JPG/460px-5_preformed_wreath_205.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/4a/5_preformed_wreath_205.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":396,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":653.6567164179105,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Preformed base Wreath. 1–If using a wreath base, you can simply hot glue or wire each ball onto the base in a pleasing pattern. 2–If using galvanized wire, {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/6_wire_loop_769.JPG/459px-6_wire_loop_769.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/5/53/6_wire_loop_769.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":505,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":834.5098039215686,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Cut your base wire to a length that will form a circle of the size you want plus 2–3 inches (5.1–7.6 cm) extra for fastening. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/89/8_sringing_too_890.JPG/460px-8_sringing_too_890.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/8/89/8_sringing_too_890.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":497,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":821.6216216216217,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Poke the wire through each ball of yarn to "string" them onto the wire. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/10_end_to_end_784.JPG/460px-10_end_to_end_784.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/ed/10_end_to_end_784.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":260,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":429.5114006514658,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}Poke the ends of the wire into the "end ball" to finish it off. Hot glue the ends together if you're concerned about the circle widening.

text:
Obtain the needed supplies. (See list at bottom of this page.) Choose yarn colors that coordinate with each other. This can easily become a Christmas wreath with red and green yarn colors, an Easter wreath with pastels, a spring wreath with pale green, blue and yellow, etc etc. Wrap each ball of yarn, either from yarn alone, or using a Styrofoam ball as a base to conserve yarn. Fasten the ends of the yarn securely with a pin or glue. Make at least 20 balls, using your wreath form as a guide so you know how many you need to cover it. Fasten the balls onto or into a wreath form. There are two easy ways to handle this. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/5_preformed_wreath_205.JPG/460px-5_preformed_wreath_205.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/4a/5_preformed_wreath_205.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":396,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":653.6567164179105,"licensing":"

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Preformed base Wreath. 1–If using a wreath base, you can simply hot glue or wire each ball onto the base in a pleasing pattern. 2–If using galvanized wire, {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/6_wire_loop_769.JPG/459px-6_wire_loop_769.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/5/53/6_wire_loop_769.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":505,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":834.5098039215686,"licensing":"

"}Cut your base wire to a length that will form a circle of the size you want plus 2–3 inches (5.1–7.6 cm) extra for fastening. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/89/8_sringing_too_890.JPG/460px-8_sringing_too_890.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/8/89/8_sringing_too_890.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":497,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":821.6216216216217,"licensing":"

"}Poke the wire through each ball of yarn to "string" them onto the wire. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/10_end_to_end_784.JPG/460px-10_end_to_end_784.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/ed/10_end_to_end_784.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":260,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":429.5114006514658,"licensing":"

"}Poke the ends of the wire into the "end ball" to finish it off. Hot glue the ends together if you're concerned about the circle widening.
sentences: (See list at bottom of this page.)
Choose yarn colors that coordinate with each other.
This can easily become a Christmas wreath with red and green yarn colors, an Easter wreath with pastels, a spring wreath with pale green, blue and yellow, etc etc.
Wrap each ball of yarn, either from yarn alone, or using a Styrofoam ball as a base to conserve yarn.
Fasten the ends of the yarn securely with a pin or glue.
Make at least 20 balls, using your wreath form as a guide so you know how many you need to cover it.
Fasten the balls onto or into a wreath form.
There are two easy ways to handle this.

tyn_section: Wire wreath base OR heavy galvanized wire
Styrofoam balls for base of yarn balls. (optional)
Hot Glue or thin wire for fastening
